Flexible Vertical Federated Learning with Heterogeneous Parties

Timothy Castiglia, Shiqiang Wang, and Stacy Patterson T. Castiglia and S. Patterson are with the Department of Computer Science, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 110 8th St, Troy, NY 12180 USA, castit@rpi.edu, sep@cs.rpi.edu. S. Wang is with the IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598 USA, wangshiq@us.ibm.com.
Abstract

We propose Flexible Vertical Federated Learning (Flex-VFL), a distributed machine algorithm that trains a smooth, non-convex function in a distributed system with vertically partitioned data. We consider a system with several parties that wish to collaboratively learn a global function. Each party holds a local dataset; the datasets have different features but share the same sample ID space. The parties are heterogeneous in nature: the parties‚Äô operating speeds, local model architectures, and optimizers may be different from one another and, further, they may change over time. To train a global model in such a system, Flex-VFL utilizes a form of parallel block coordinate descent, where parties train a partition of the global model via stochastic coordinate descent. We provide theoretical convergence analysis for Flex-VFL and show that the convergence rate is constrained by the party speeds and local optimizer parameters. We apply this analysis and extend our algorithm to adapt party learning rates in response to changing speeds and local optimizer parameters. Finally, we compare the convergence time of Flex-VFL against synchronous and asynchronous VFL algorithms, as well as illustrate the effectiveness of our adaptive extension.

I Introduction

In modern distributed systems, data are often generated by multiple parties and must remain on premises to follow regulations (e.g., GDPR¬†[1], HIPAA¬†[2]) and protect sensitive personal information. Federated learning algorithms¬†[3, 4, 5] were introduced to provide methods for training machine learning models in distributed systems without the need to share raw data between parties. In these algorithms, data-owning parties train models locally and share intermediate information with a parameter server to update the global model. Federated learning has many important applications including personalized healthcare, smart transportation, and predictive energy systems¬†[4, 6].

Vertical Federated Learning (VFL) is an important class of federated learning. In VFL, parties‚Äô local datasets share a common sample ID space but have different feature sets¬†[5, 7, 8]. This is in contrast to Horizontal Federated Learning (HFL), where all parties‚Äô datasets share the same feature space, but each party‚Äôs data corresponds to a distinct set of sample IDs¬†[3, 9, 10, 11, 12]. For example, consider a case where a healthcare provider, insurance company, and wearable device manufacturer wish to collaboratively train a model to identify diseases without directly sharing raw user information with one another¬†[13]. These parties store information about the same people, but each party has a distinct set of information for each individual. In VFL, each party typically trains a local feature extractor, while a central server trains a fusion model. The parties periodically exchange intermediate information for updating their local models. We provide an example of a VFL model setup in Figure¬†1.

Many VFL algorithms assume parties have identical local training: each party uses the same local optimizer to update its model, typically standard SGD¬†[7, 14, 15, 8, 16, 17, 18]. However, in practice, parties store different types of feature sets ranging from medical images to income values. Centralized machine learning accommodates such multimodal data by supporting different local feature extractors and optimizers for each feature set¬†[19, 20, 21, 22]. However, such heterogeneous local optimizers have not been accommodated in previous VFL works.

Additionally, it is typically assumed that each party takes the same amount of time to update its local model. The complexity of a party‚Äôs model and choice of local optimizer can affect its local training time. There can also be differences in party operating rates due to differing compute capabilities or a varying workload in each party due to colocated jobs. Further, a party‚Äôs operating rate may change over time. The slowest parties in the system, the stragglers, can become a bottleneck in the convergence of VFL algorithms¬†[23, 24, 25].

Previous VFL works have addressed some of these issues. Asynchronous VFL algorithms¬†[14, 16, 26, 27] were proposed as a means to avoid the straggler bottleneck. These algorithms allow parties to train at their own pace, and send updates whenever they are able. However, training with stale information for long periods has been shown to degrade overall model performance, overwhelming the benefits of flexibility to heterogeneous party operating speeds¬†[28, 29]. Some VFL algorithms using common optimizers other than standard SGD have been proposed¬†[30, 31, 32, 33, 34], but they require that all parties apply the same local optimizer for training. No previous VFL works incoporate both the effect of time-varying operating speeds and heterogeneous local optimizers.

In this work, we consider a heterogeneous VFL setting where parties have different, time-varying, operating rates and different local optimizers. We seek to answer the following questions. Is there a method of VFL that can be flexible to the inherently asynchronous nature of distributed parties? Can we analyze the effect of heterogeneous party local optimizers in a VFL setting? And finally, can we generalize the analysis to gain insight into the effect of commonly used local optimizers on VFL convergence?

To address these questions, we propose Flexible Vertical Federated Learning (Flex-VFL). Flex-VFL is a communication-efficient distributed learning algorithm for vertically partitioned data that is robust to heterogeneous party operating speeds, lets parties utilize different local feature extractors and optimizers, and supports a variety of local optimizers. In Flex-VFL, rather than the server waiting for all parties to complete a given number of local iterations, each party completes as many iterations as possible within a specified timeout. The parties synchronize with the server after this set amount of time has passed. Our approach serves as a middle-ground between fully synchronous and asynchronous methods: training is not slowed down by stragglers, but parties still synchronize regularly to avoid training with stale information for long periods of time. Further, unlike previously proposed VFL algorithms, Flex-VFL allows parties to customize their local optimizers based on their local data and feature extractor architecture.

Flex-VFL is the first theoretically-verified VFL algorithm that has convergence guarantees when parties use different local optimizers. To represent these optimizers in our analysis, we apply arbitrary weights to party gradients at each local iteration. This approach was first introduced by Wang et al.¬†[35], but it has never been applied to the VFL setting or generalized for time-varying optimizer parameters. Our convergence results are generalizable to many variations of VFL, and provides novel insights into the benefits and drawbacks of local momentum¬†[35], proximal terms¬†[36], and variable learning rates on the convergence of VFL algorithms. Specifically, we show that these optimizers improve convergence speed but may increase the error at convergence. Our analysis shows that proper tuning of party learning rates can help offset the error introduced by party heterogeneity.

Our work also provides an adaptive extension to Flex-VFL known as Adaptive Flex-VFL: a meta-optimization algorithm that improves the convergence rate. In systems where other jobs may be colocated on the participating devices, party operating speeds may vary over the course of training. In these cases, it is a challenge to choose hyperparameters to accommodate such heterogeneity over time. Based on our theoretical results on convergence in Flex-VFL, the server can gather party information in each global round to optimize the party learning rates. Adaptive Flex-VFL is designed to be robust to heterogeneous and time-varying party speeds and optimizer parameters.

Our main contributions are as follows:

  1. 1.

    We propose Flex-VFL, a Vertical Federated Learning algorithm that is robust to heterogeneous, time-varying parties. Flex-VFL supports a large class of SGD variants such as SGD with local momentum, proximal steps, and variable learning rates.

  2. 2.

    We provide convergence analysis for Flex-VFL and show that the error incurred by heterogeneous parties can be offset with the proper choice of learning rates in each round.

  3. 3.

    We propose Adaptive Flex-VFL, an extension of Flex-VFL where each party‚Äôs learning rate is tailored to its speed and optimizer parameters at each round.

  4. 4.

    We experimentally compare Flex-VFL with other VFL algorithms using both simulated and real-world party operating speeds. We find that Flex-VFL outperforms purely synchronous and asynchronous VFL algorithms, reaching target accuracy up to 4√ó4\times as fast. We also compare Adaptive Flex-VFL and Flex-VFL using real-world time-varying party operating speeds, and show up to a 30%percent3030\% time-to-target improvement.

The rest of the paper is structured as follows. In Section¬†II we discuss related work. Section¬†III introduces our system model and problem formulation. We present Flex-VFL in Section¬†IV. We analyze the convergence of our algorithm in Section¬†V, and present an optimization method to improve convergence speed by adapting party learning rates in Section¬†VI. In Section¬†VII we present our experiments. Finally, we conclude in Section¬†VIII.

II Related Work

Many works in HFL tackle the challenges of high-latency communication with the use of local iterations. These works analyze the effect of local iterations on convergence¬†[9, 37, 12]. Castiglia et al.¬†[38] and Wang et al.¬†[35] both propose HFL algorithms that support heterogeneous party operating speeds, MLL-SGD¬†[38] and FedNova¬†[35]. FedNova also supports several common local optimizers, such as SGD with proximal steps and local momentum. Both these works provide analysis that give insight into the benefit of supporting these features in federated learning algorithms. However, these previous works in HFL cannot be applied to the VFL case. HFL algorithms rely on distributed gradient descent methods and share model parameter updates, while most VFL algorithms utilize distributed coordinate descent methods and share the output of feature extractors. Thus, the algorithms and analyses for VFL algorithms are fundamentally different.

VFL algorithms are typically variations of coordinate descent methods. Parallel and distributed coordinate descent methods have been proposed¬†[39, 40, 41], but these works depend on a shared memory structure or data sharing between parties, which is not applicable to the VFL setting. Several works have proposed variants of distributed coordinate descent methods for VFL. Many early works do not include support for multiple local iterations¬†[42, 43, 44]. Without support for multiple local iterations, progress in optimization is limited by communication time with the server, which can be costly in cases of high communication latency. Some works propose synchronous VFL algorithms that support multiple local iterations¬†[15, 7, 8, 17, 18]. However, these algorithms require all parties to use the same standard SGD local optimizer. Xie et al.¬†[34] propose a synchronous VFL algorithm with multiple local iterations using an ADMM-based optimizer. However, all parties use the same local optimizer in their method, and the fusion network is limited to a linear model, reducing the types of model architectures supported. Additionally, all of these algorithms require that all parties run the same number of local iterations, allowing stragglers to create a bottleneck in training time.

Several works propose asynchronous VFL algorithm¬†[16, 14, 26, 27], but the algorithms do not support multiple local iterations. Additionally, these algorithms only support SGD local updates. Gu et al.¬†[32] and Zhang et al.¬†[33] propose several asynchronous VFL algorithms that support local iterations and common optimizers other than SGD. However, the schemes employed require that each party uses a linear model, which limits the use cases of the proposed algorithms. Their algorithms also do not support parties using different local optimizers in the same algorithm execution.

In contrast with previous work, our work jointly provides support and analyzes the effects of party heterogeneity, time-varying speeds, and limited bandwidth in a VFL setting. Specifically, each party can execute a different number of local iterations in each round, and this number of local iterations can change over time. Further, we provide an analysis of our algorithm that includes the impact of this heterogeneity on the convergence rate and convergence error. These features in our algorithm and analysis allow us to model a more realistic VFL scenario and gives us insight into how to adapt party learning rates to mitigate the error introduced by party heterogeneity.

Smoothness: There exists positive constants L<‚àûL{L<\infty} and Lk<‚àûsubscriptLk{L_{k}<\infty} for k=0,‚Ä¶,Kk0‚Ä¶Kk=0,...,K such that for all ùöØ1‚àà‚ÑùVsubscriptùöØ1superscript‚ÑùV{\bm{\Theta}_{1}\in\mathbb{R}^{V}}, ùöØ2‚àà‚ÑùVsubscriptùöØ2superscript‚ÑùV\bm{\Theta}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{V}:

‚Äñ‚àáùúΩkli‚Äã(ùöØ1)‚àí‚àáùúΩkli‚Äã(ùöØ2)‚Äñnormsubscript‚àásubscriptùúΩùëòsubscriptùëôùëñsubscriptùöØ1subscript‚àásubscriptùúΩùëòsubscriptùëôùëñsubscriptùöØ2\displaystyle\left\|\nabla_{\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}}l_{i}(\bm{\Theta}_{1})-\nabla_{\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}}l_{i}(\bm{\Theta}_{2})\right\| ‚â§Lk‚Äã‚ÄñùöØ1‚àíùöØ2‚Äñ.absentsubscriptùêøùëònormsubscriptùöØ1subscriptùöØ2\displaystyle\leq L_{k}\left\|\bm{\Theta}_{1}-\bm{\Theta}_{2}\right\|. (3)
Assumption 2.

Unbiased gradients: For a mini-batch ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}, for k=0,‚Ä¶,Kk0‚Ä¶Kk=0,...,K, the stochastic partial derivatives are unbiased, i.e., for all ùöØ‚àà‚ÑùVùöØsuperscript‚ÑùV\bm{\Theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{V}

ùîº‚Ñ¨‚Äã[ùíàk‚Äã(ùöØ)]subscriptùîº‚Ñ¨delimited-[]subscriptùíàùëòùöØ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}}\left[\bm{g}_{k}(\bm{\Theta})\right] =‚àákF‚Äã(ùöØ).absentsubscript‚àáùëòùêπùöØ\displaystyle=\nabla_{k}F(\bm{\Theta}). (4)
Assumption 3.

Bounded variance: There exists constants œÉk<‚àûsubscriptœÉk{\sigma_{k}<\infty} for k=0,‚Ä¶,Kk0‚Ä¶Kk=0,...,K such that the variances of the stochastic partial derivatives are bounded as

ùîº‚Ñ¨‚Äã‚Äñ‚àákF‚Äã(ùöØ)‚àíùíàk‚Äã(ùöØ)‚Äñ2subscriptùîº‚Ñ¨superscriptnormsubscript‚àáùëòùêπùöØsubscriptùíàùëòùöØ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}}{\left\|\nabla_{k}F(\bm{\Theta})-\bm{g}_{k}(\bm{\Theta})\right\|^{2}} ‚â§œÉk2absentsuperscriptsubscriptùúéùëò2\displaystyle\leq\sigma_{k}^{2} (5)

for a mini-batch ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\operatorname{\mathcal{B}} and for all ùöØ‚àà‚ÑùVùöØsuperscript‚Ñùùëâ\bm{\Theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{V}.

Assumption¬†1 bounds how fast the gradient and partial derivatives can change. Assumption¬†2 requires that the stochastic partial derivatives computed by each party and the server are unbiased estimates of the full-batch partial derivatives. Assumption¬†2 can be satisfied in practice by ensuring that sample IDs for a mini-batch are chosen at random. Note, we make no assumption about the distribution of the full dataset XX\operatorname{\textbf{X}}. Finally, Assumption¬†3 bounds the variance between the stochastic partial derivatives and full-batch partial derivatives by some constant.

IV Algorithm

We now present Flex-VFL, our algorithm for training a global model with distributed, vertically partitioned data in a system with heterogeneous parties. In each global round of Flex-VFL, we employ a type of parallel stochastic block coordinate descent. Each party and the server updates its coordinate partition using its local optimizer for one or more local iterations. The parties complete as many of these local iterations as possible before a specified timeout. This differs from synchronous VFL algorithms that wait for all parties to complete the same number of local iterations¬†[7], which can lead to a bottleneck when slow parties are present. We assume that all parties participate in each global round and run at least one local iteration before the given timeout. Flex-VFL runs RùëÖR global rounds of training.

One of the challenges in training for our objective is distributing the necessary information for parties to compute their partial derivatives. For a given data sample xx\operatorname{\textbf{x}} and its label yùë¶y, the server must compute:

ùíà0‚Äã(ùöØ;x)=‚àáùúΩ0l‚Äã(ùúΩ0;ùíâ1‚Äã(ùúΩ1;x1),‚Ä¶,ùíâK‚Äã(ùúΩK;xK);y)subscriptùíà0ùöØxsubscript‚àásubscriptùúΩ0ùëôsubscriptùúΩ0subscriptùíâ1subscriptùúΩ1subscriptx1‚Ä¶subscriptùíâùêæsubscriptùúΩùêæsubscriptxùêæùë¶\displaystyle\bm{g}_{0}(\bm{\Theta};\operatorname{\textbf{x}})=\nabla_{\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0}}l(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0};\bm{h}_{1}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{1};\operatorname{\textbf{x}}_{1}),...,\bm{h}_{K}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{K};\operatorname{\textbf{x}}_{K});y)

and each party kùëòk must compute:

ùíàk‚Äã(ùöØ;x)=‚àáùúΩkl‚Äã(ùúΩ0;ùíâ1‚Äã(ùúΩ1;x1),‚Ä¶,ùíâK‚Äã(ùúΩK;xK);y)subscriptùíàùëòùöØxsubscript‚àásubscriptùúΩùëòùëôsubscriptùúΩ0subscriptùíâ1subscriptùúΩ1subscriptx1‚Ä¶subscriptùíâùêæsubscriptùúΩùêæsubscriptxùêæùë¶\displaystyle\bm{g}_{k}(\bm{\Theta};\operatorname{\textbf{x}})=\nabla_{\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}}l(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0};\bm{h}_{1}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{1};\operatorname{\textbf{x}}_{1}),...,\bm{h}_{K}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{K};\operatorname{\textbf{x}}_{K});y)
=‚àáùúΩkùíâk‚Äã(ùúΩk)‚ä§‚Äã‚àáùíâk‚Äã(ùúΩk)l‚Äã(ùúΩ0;ùíâ1‚Äã(ùúΩ1;x1),‚Ä¶,ùíâK‚Äã(ùúΩK;xK);y).absentsubscript‚àásubscriptùúΩùëòsubscriptùíâùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòtopsubscript‚àásubscriptùíâùëòsubscriptùúΩùëòùëôsubscriptùúΩ0subscriptùíâ1subscriptùúΩ1subscriptx1‚Ä¶subscriptùíâùêæsubscriptùúΩùêæsubscriptxùêæùë¶\displaystyle=\nabla_{\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}}\bm{h}_{k}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k})^{\top}\nabla_{\bm{h}_{k}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k})}l(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0};\bm{h}_{1}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{1};\operatorname{\textbf{x}}_{1}),...,\bm{h}_{K}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{K};\operatorname{\textbf{x}}_{K});y).

We can see that for a party to calculate its model update, it needs to first calculate ‚àáùíâk‚Äã(ùúΩk)l‚Äã(ùúΩ0;ùíâ1‚Äã(ùúΩ1;x1),‚Ä¶,ùíâK‚Äã(ùúΩK;xK);y)subscript‚àásubscriptùíâùëòsubscriptùúΩùëòùëôsubscriptùúΩ0subscriptùíâ1subscriptùúΩ1subscriptx1‚Ä¶subscriptùíâùêæsubscriptùúΩùêæsubscriptxùêæùë¶\nabla_{\bm{h}_{k}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k})}l(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0};\bm{h}_{1}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{1};\operatorname{\textbf{x}}_{1}),...,\bm{h}_{K}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{K};\operatorname{\textbf{x}}_{K});y). Thus, to execute multiple local iterations on a data sample¬†xx\operatorname{\textbf{x}} without communication, each party and the server will need to receive a snapshot of the embeddings ùíâj‚Äã(ùúΩj)subscriptùíâùëósubscriptùúΩùëó\bm{h}_{j}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{j}) for all j‚â†kùëóùëòj\neq k and the server model ùúΩ0subscriptùúΩ0\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0} at the start of each global round. We describe the process of exchanging this information below. Moving forward, the superscript r,tùëüùë°r,t denotes global round rùëür at local iteration tùë°t. We let the snapshot of embeddings for a mini-batch at round rùëür be denoted Œ¶r={ùúΩ0r,0,ùíâ1‚Äã(ùúΩ1r,0;X1‚Ñ¨),‚Ä¶,ùíâK‚Äã(ùúΩKr,0;XK‚Ñ¨)}superscriptŒ¶ùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩ0ùëü0subscriptùíâ1superscriptsubscriptùúΩ1ùëü0superscriptsubscriptX1‚Ñ¨‚Ä¶subscriptùíâùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùêæùëü0superscriptsubscriptXùêæ‚Ñ¨\Phi^{r}=\{\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0}^{r,0},\bm{h}_{1}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{1}^{r,0};\operatorname{\textbf{X}}_{1}^{\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}}),\ldots,\bm{h}_{K}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{K}^{r,0};\operatorname{\textbf{X}}_{K}^{\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}})\}.

We describe the training process of Flex-VFL in Algorithm¬†1. The global model is initialized to ùöØ0,0=[ùúΩ00,0,‚Ä¶,ùúΩK0,0]superscriptùöØ00superscriptsubscriptùúΩ000‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùúΩùêæ00\bm{\Theta}^{0,0}=[\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0}^{0,0},...,\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{K}^{0,0}]. In each global round, the parties agree upon a mini-batch of sample IDs ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\operatorname{\mathcal{B}} on which to train. For example, the server may assign the same random number generator seed to all parties, ensuring each party chooses the same sample IDs at the start of each round. Each party then determines its set of local features Xk‚Ñ¨superscriptsubscriptXùëò‚Ñ¨\operatorname{\textbf{X}}_{k}^{\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}} that it will use to compute embeddings. Each party, excluding the server, computes its embeddings for the mini-batch, ùíâk‚Äã(ùúΩk;Xk‚Ñ¨)subscriptùíâùëòsubscriptùúΩùëòsubscriptsuperscriptX‚Ñ¨ùëò\bm{h}_{k}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k};\operatorname{\textbf{X}}^{\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}}_{k}). These embeddings are sent to the server, and the server distributes its current model ùúΩ0subscriptùúΩ0\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0} and Œ¶rsuperscriptŒ¶ùëü\Phi^{r} to all parties.

Next, each party and the server start the local training period. Each party and the server run as many local gradient descent steps as it can within a timeout that is pre-specified before training begins. We let œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} be the number of local gradient descent steps that party kùëòk completes in round rùëür, with 1‚â§œÑkr<‚àû1superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü1\leq\tau_{k}^{r}<\infty. This number of local iterations œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} depends on party kùëòk‚Äôs operating speed in global round rùëür and the local training timeout. Slower parties have smaller œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} values, while faster parties have larger œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} values. Since computation loads may change over time, a party‚Äôs operating speed, and thus its œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r}, may change between each global round. Note that during local iterations, each party only updates its own embedding ùíâk‚Äã(ùúΩkr,t)subscriptùíâùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëüùë°\bm{h}_{k}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}^{r,t}), and uses stale versions of ùíâj‚Äã(ùúΩjr,0)subscriptùíâùëósuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëóùëü0\bm{h}_{j}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{j}^{r,0}) for all j‚â†kùëóùëòj\neq k. Each party also reuses the same mini-batch for œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} iterations, saving on communication of a new set of embeddings at each local iteration. We show in Section¬†V that the model converges, even though this stale information is used.

A party kùëòk‚Äôs updates during each local iteration are defined as follows:

ùúΩkr,t+1=ùúΩkr,t‚àíŒ∑kr‚ÄãDk‚Äã(Œ¶‚àíkr;ùúΩkr,0,‚Ä¶,ùúΩkr,t;y‚Ñ¨)superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëüùë°1superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëüùë°superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëüsubscriptDùëòsuperscriptsubscriptŒ¶ùëòùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëü0‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëüùë°superscripty‚Ñ¨\displaystyle\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}^{r,t+1}=\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}^{r,t}-\eta_{k}^{r}\textbf{D}_{k}\left(\Phi_{-k}^{r};\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}^{r,0},\ldots,\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}^{r,t};\operatorname{\textbf{y}}^{\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}}\right) (6)

where Œ¶‚àíkrsuperscriptsubscriptŒ¶ùëòùëü\Phi_{-k}^{r} is the set of all embeddings except those from party kùëòk, and Dk‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptDùëò‚ãÖ\textbf{D}_{k}(\cdot) is the local optimizer update rule based on the stochastic partial derivatives from the start of the global round to the current local iteration. This method of generalizing to several local optimizers was first shown in the context of HFL by Wang et al.¬†[35]. However it has yet to be analyzed in the context of VFL, which provides its own unique challenges. We discuss this more in Section¬†V.

Communication cost: The size of messages in Flex-VFL is of note. For each party to compute its partial derivative, every party must exchange its embeddings for the current mini-batch, and the server must send its model ùúΩ0subscriptùúΩ0\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0} to the parties. Let the size of the kùëòk-th embedding for a single data sample be OksubscriptùëÇùëòO_{k}. The total amount of data sent per global round is then K‚Äã(|ùúΩ0|+B‚Äã‚àëk=1KOk)ùêæsubscriptùúΩ0ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùëÇùëòK(|\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{0}|+B\sum_{k=1}^{K}O_{k}).

Privacy: HFL algorithms typically share model updates or gradient information in messages. Gradients can potentially leak raw data information, as shown in previous work¬†[48, 49]. However, in Flex-VFL, messages only contain embeddings and each party can only calculate the partial derivatives associated with the server model and its local model. Thus, gradient attacks proposed for HFL cannot be performed on Flex-VFL. Embeddings may be vulnerable to model inversion attacks¬†[50], though these attacks can be mitigated by applying homomorphic encryption¬†[51, 44] or secure multi-party computation¬†[32] to Flex-VFL. As mentioned in Section¬†III, we assume that all parties have access to the labels. There are many practical scenarios where data samples are private between the parties, but the labels are not, such as predicting credit score. However, if labels are private and only present at a single party, Flex-VFL can be augmented using the method proposed by Liu et al.¬†[7], allowing gradient calculation without the need for sharing labels. The analysis in Section¬†V still holds in this case.

V Analysis

In this section, we provide convergence analysis of Flex-VFL. (9)

We can define our updates to the global model during a global round with the following recurrence relation:

ùöØr+1,0=ùöØr,0‚àíŒ∑kr‚ÄãGr.superscriptùöØùëü10superscriptùöØùëü0superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëüsuperscriptGùëü\displaystyle\bm{\Theta}^{r+1,0}=\bm{\Theta}^{r,0}-\eta_{k}^{r}\operatorname{\textbf{G}}^{r}. (10)

With the help of (10), we can model Flex-VFL as a gradient coordinate descent algorithm and analyze the algorithm convergence in this vein.

We note that each party reuses stale embeddings of the same mini-batch from other parties for multiple local iterations in Algorithm¬†1: each party kùëòk takes œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} descent steps using mini-batch ‚Ñ¨rsuperscript‚Ñ¨ùëü\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}^{r} at a global round rùëür. This indicates that the stochastic gradients are not unbiased during local iterations t>0ùë°0t>0. However, using conditional expectation, we can apply Assumption¬†2 to the gradient calculated at local iteration t=0ùë°0t=0. If we take expectation over ‚Ñ¨rsuperscript‚Ñ¨ùëü\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}^{r}, conditioned on the previous models ùöØœÑ,0superscriptùöØùúè0\bm{\Theta}^{\tau,0} up to round rùëür, we obtain

ùîº‚Ñ¨r‚Äã[ùíàkr,0|{ùöØœÑ,0}œÑ=0r]=‚àámF‚Äã(Œ¶‚àíkr;ùíâk‚Äã(ùúΩkr,t)).subscriptùîºsuperscript‚Ñ¨ùëüdelimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptùíàùëòùëü0superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùöØùúè0ùúè0ùëüsubscript‚àáùëöùêπsuperscriptsubscriptŒ¶ùëòùëüsubscriptùíâùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúΩùëòùëüùë°\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\operatorname{\mathcal{B}}^{r}}[\bm{g}_{k}^{r,0}\leavevmode\nobreak\ |\leavevmode\nobreak\ \{\bm{\Theta}^{\tau,0}\}_{\tau=0}^{r}]=\nabla_{m}F(\Phi_{-k}^{r};\bm{h}_{k}(\operatorname{\bm{\theta}}_{k}^{r,t})). (11)

With the help of (11), we can prove convergence by bounding the difference between the gradient at the start of each global round and those calculated during local iterations.

The proof of Lemma¬†1 can be found in Appendix¬†-B. Lemma¬†1 bounds the error incurred at each party in the stochastic partial derivatives during a set of local iterations as a result of using stale embeddings from other parties, as well as from using the same mini-batch for all local iterations in a single round. The lemma also captures the effect of different local optimizers at each party on the partial derivatives. Using Lemma¬†1, we can now analyze how this error accumulates over all iterations. Applying our smoothness assumption along with (10) and Lemma¬†1, we can prove that Flex-VFL converges.

We present our convergence result in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Under Assumptions¬†1‚Äì3, if Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} satisfies:

We provide the full proof of Theorem¬†1 in Appendix¬†-C.

The left-hand-side of (15) is a weighted average of all the partial derivatives‚Äô norms during the training. As this term approaches zero, Flex-VFL approaches a fixed point. The first term in the right-hand-side of (15) is similar to that of distributed gradient descent¬†[45], and is affected by the difference in the initial and final models of the algorithm. The first term is the convergence rate term: as the number of global rounds RùëÖR approaches ‚àû\infty, this first term goes to zero, while the second term, the additive convergence error, remains. The second term is the error associated with the variance in taking stochastic gradients steps, as well as the error incurred by running multiple local iterations.

If we let Œ∑kr=1R‚Äãmaxk,r‚Å°œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü1ùëÖsubscriptùëòùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{R\max_{k,r}\tau_{k}^{r}}} in (15), then we can see the convergence rate of Flex-VFL is O‚Äã(1R‚Äãmaxk,r‚Å°œÑkr)ùëÇ1ùëÖsubscriptùëòùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëüO(\frac{1}{\sqrt{R\max_{k,r}\tau_{k}^{r}}}), the same as other VFL algorithms¬†[7, 14, 16]. This indicates that we can achieve a fast convergence speed despite the error introduced by heterogeneous party speeds and local optimizers.

Effect of heterogeneous speeds: We observe that SùëÜS appears in the denominator of the first term in¬†(15); a larger value of SùëÜS improves the convergence rate of Flex-VFL. This quantity SùëÜS depends on the party learning rates Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} and the constraint (14) requires that Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} be inversely proportional to œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r}, the number of local iterations party kùëòk takes in round rùëür. In addition, SùëÜS increases with the sum of weights wkr,tsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëòùëüùë°w_{k}^{r,t} over œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} local iterations. Consider the case where each party employs classical SGD, implying wkr,t=1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëòùëüùë°1w_{k}^{r,t}=1 for all parties over all iterations. In this case, S=‚àër=0R‚àí1‚àëk=0KŒ∑kr‚ÄãœÑkrùëÜsuperscriptsubscriptùëü0ùëÖ1superscriptsubscriptùëò0ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëüS=\sum_{r=0}^{R-1}\sum_{k=0}^{K}\eta_{k}^{r}\tau_{k}^{r}. If we let Œ∑kr=1œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü1superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r}=\frac{1}{\tau_{k}^{r}}, then S=R‚Äã(K+1)ùëÜùëÖùêæ1S=R(K+1). If we instead consider a fixed learning rate Œ∑kr=Œ∑superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëüùúÇ\eta_{k}^{r}=\eta across all parties and iterations, then to satisfy (14), Œ∑=1maxk,r‚Å°œÑkrùúÇ1subscriptùëòùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\eta=\frac{1}{\max_{k,r}\tau_{k}^{r}}. Thus, choosing the learning rates Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} according to each party‚Äôs number of local iterations in a round œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} can reduce the error in the first term of (15) and improve the convergence rate. However, œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} may not always be known in advance. We discuss these findings further in Section¬†VI, where we introduce Adaptive Flex-VFL.

Effect of heterogeneous optimizers: From Theorem¬†1, we can see that the first term in (15) decreases with larger local optimizer weights, while the second term increases with larger weights. Note that proper tuning of Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} for each party kùëòk can help offset the error introduced by max0‚â§t‚â§œÑkr‚àí1‚Å°wtsubscript0ùë°superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü1superscriptùë§ùë°\max_{0\leq t\leq\tau_{k}^{r}-1}w^{t} in the second term. We also note that the constraint (14) requires Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} to be inversely proportional max0‚â§t‚â§œÑkr‚àí1‚Å°wtsubscript0ùë°superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü1superscriptùë§ùë°\max_{0\leq t\leq\tau_{k}^{r}-1}w^{t}. Thus there is tension between choosing larger optimizer weights and choosing a larger step size. In cases where Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} remains constant while still satisfying (14), Theorem¬†1 indicates that weights larger than 111, such as when using momentum and proximal steps, can improve the convergence rate by decreasing the first term in (15). However, it can also negatively affect the error as R‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÖR\rightarrow\infty by increasing the second term in (15). If all else is constant, a large WkrsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùëòùëüW_{k}^{r} is beneficial when œÉksubscriptùúéùëò\sigma_{k} is small. In other words, in cases where stochastic variance is small, our analysis shows a potential benefit for using local optimizers other than classical SGD.

We now introduce some corollaries to study the convergence rate of Flex-VFL. We first consider the case where each party has the same stochastic variance, runs the same number of local iterations, and uses SGD locally.

Corollary 1.

Suppose œÉk=œÉsubscriptùúéùëòùúé\sigma_{k}=\sigma, œÑkr=œÑsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëüùúè\tau_{k}^{r}=\tau, and Œ∑kr=Œ∑superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëüùúÇ\eta_{k}^{r}=\eta for all parties kùëòk and rounds rùëür. 1R‚Äã‚àër=0R‚àí1ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñ‚àáF‚Äã(ùöØr,0)‚Äñ2]1ùëÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëü0ùëÖ1ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnorm‚àáùêπsuperscriptùöØùëü02\displaystyle\frac{1}{R}\sum_{r=0}^{R-1}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla F(\bm{\Theta}^{r,0})\right\|^{2}\right] ‚â§4‚Äã(F‚Äã(ùöØ0,0)‚àíFinf)R‚ÄãŒ∑‚ÄãœÑ‚Äã(K+1)+4‚ÄãL‚ÄãŒ∑‚ÄãœÑ‚ÄãœÉ2absent4ùêπsuperscriptùöØ00superscriptFinfùëÖùúÇùúèùêæ14ùêøùúÇùúèsuperscriptùúé2\displaystyle\leq\frac{4(F(\bm{\Theta}^{0,0})-\operatorname{F^{\mathrm{inf}}})}{R\eta\tau(K+1)}+4L\eta\tau\sigma^{2} (17)

We consider a decaying learning rate in the following corollary.

Corollary 2.

Suppose Œ∑kr‚â§116‚ÄãœÑkr‚Äãmax‚Å°{L,Lk}‚Äãmax0‚â§t‚â§œÑkr‚àí1‚Å°wkr,tsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü116superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëüùêøsubscriptùêøùëòsubscript0ùë°superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëòùëüùë°\eta_{k}^{r}\leq\frac{1}{16\tau_{k}^{r}\max\{L,L_{k}\}\max_{0\leq t\leq\tau_{k}^{r}-1}w_{k}^{r,t}}, and suppose that ‚àër=0‚àûŒ∑kr=‚àûsuperscriptsubscriptùëü0superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\sum_{r=0}^{\infty}\eta_{k}^{r}=\infty and ‚àër=0‚àû(Œ∑kr)2<‚àûsuperscriptsubscriptùëü0superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü2\sum_{r=0}^{\infty}(\eta_{k}^{r})^{2}<\infty for all parties kùëòk. Then under Assumptions¬†1-3, the left-hand-side of (15) goes to zero as RùëÖR approaches ‚àû\infty.

Corollary¬†2 states that given a sequence of learning rates that are not summable, but square summable, then Algorithm¬†1 achieves convergence to a fixed point. One possible choice for learning rates to satisfy these conditions is by diminishing Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} at a rate of O‚Äã(1r)ùëÇ1ùëüO\left(\frac{1}{r}\right) where rùëür is the current global round. This is a standard step size requirement of SGD algorithms for non-convex objectives¬†[45].

VI Adaptive Extension

In this section, we present an adaptive extension to Flex-VFL, which we call Adaptive Flex-VFL. One can think of Adaptive Flex-VFL as a meta-optimization algorithm where the server keeps track of party operating speeds and local optimizer parameters during each global round in order to choose the best learning rates for convergence speed.

Let w¬Økr‚âîmax0‚â§t‚â§œÑkr‚àí1‚Äãwkr,t‚âîsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùë§ùëòùëü0ùë°superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëòùëüùë°\bar{w}_{k}^{r}\coloneqq\underset{0\leq t\leq\tau_{k}^{r}-1}{\max}w_{k}^{r,t}. According to Theorem¬†1, the learning rate Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} at a given global round rùëür for party kùëòk must be inversely proportional to the number of local iterations œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} and the largest weight applied during local iterations w¬Økrsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùë§ùëòùëü\bar{w}_{k}^{r}. We also know that the first term of (15) is the main contributor to the convergence rate in Flex-VFL, while the second term is the convergence floor, mostly affected by the stochastic variance. If the bound (14) on the learning rates Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} holds, the second term‚Äôs effect is minimal. Therefore, based on our analysis, a natural improvement to Flex-VFL is to maximize Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} subject to (14) in each global round, tailoring each party‚Äôs learning rate to their specific operating rate and local optimizer parameters.

Adaptive Flex-VFL is outlined in Algorithm¬†2. For the first global round, œÑk0superscriptsubscriptùúèùëò0\tau_{k}^{0} for each party is estimated, either with prior knowledge of the party operating speeds, or by running a dummy global round. Each party can communicate w¬Øk0superscriptsubscript¬Øùë§ùëò0\bar{w}_{k}^{0} to the server before the start of training. All Œ∑k1superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëò1\eta_{k}^{1} are initialized to some AkœÑk0‚Äãw¬Øk0subscriptùê¥ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëò0superscriptsubscript¬Øùë§ùëò0\frac{A_{k}}{\tau_{k}^{0}\bar{w}_{k}^{0}}, where Aksubscriptùê¥ùëòA_{k} is chosen small enough to satisfy (14). At the end of each global round, the server gathers information about how many local iterations each party took, œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r}, and their maximum weight applied to gradients during local iterations, w¬Økrsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùë§ùëòùëü\bar{w}_{k}^{r}. We let Œ∑kr+1=AkœÑkr‚Äãw¬ØkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü1subscriptùê¥ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëüsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùë§ùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r+1}=\frac{A_{k}}{\tau_{k}^{r}\bar{w}_{k}^{r}}. If we assume that for each party kùëòk, œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} and wkr,tsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëòùëüùë°w_{k}^{r,t} do not change too rapidly across global rounds, the server can accurately estimate the appropriate learning rate to assign to each party that will maximize the convergence rate.

We now define more formal conditions under which Adaptive Flex-VFL is guaranteed to converge according to Theorem¬†1. Suppose the maximum rate of change of œÑkr‚Äãw¬Økrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëüsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùë§ùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r}\bar{w}_{k}^{r} from a round rùëür to r+1ùëü1r+1 is Œ±ùõº\alpha:

VII Experiments

Next, we present experiments to compare Flex-VFL with synchronous and asynchronous VFL algorithms, and to observe the effect of the adaptive extension to Flex-VFL in practice.111 Code for experiments available at https://github.com/rpi-nsl/flex-vfl

VII-A Datasets and Experimental Setup

We utilize three datasets for our experiments: the MOSEI dataset¬†[53], the ImageNet dataset¬†[54], and the ModelNet40 dataset¬†[55]. For each dataset and VFL algorithm, we performed a grid search to choose the best learning rate and regularization parameters (where applicable); we trained each algorithm with different hyperparameters for 100100100 epochs and chose the hyperparameters with the lowest training loss.

MOSEI: CMU-MOSEI is a multimodal dataset for sentiment analysis. The dataset consists of 232323,453453453 sentences from YouTube videos giving opinions on various topics. The dataset includes video, audio, and text data, and each sentence is labeled with sentiment values, scoring the positivity or negativity of the sentence. For our experimental setup, we consider a case with three parties, where each party stores one type of data. The parties with video and audio train local LSTMs, and the party with text trains a BERT model. The server model consists of a three-layer fully-connected neural network. We use an L1 loss function with L2 regularization. The parties train using SGD with a batch size of 505050. For the video and audio parties the learning rate was selected from {0.01,0.005,0.001,0.0005}0.010.0050.0010.0005\{0.01,0.005,0.001,0.0005\}. For the text party the learning rate was selected from {0.000‚Äâ05,0.000‚Äâ01,0.000‚Äâ005}0.000050.000010.000005\{$0.000\,05$,$0.000\,01$,$0.000\,005$\} The regularization coefficient was selected from {0,10‚àí3,10‚àí4,10‚àí5}0superscript103superscript104superscript105\{0,10^{-3},10^{-4},10^{-5}\}.

ImageNet100: The ImageNet dataset consists of images from several classes of objects. In our experiments, we randomly choose 100100100 classes from the ImageNet dataset (ImageNet100), consisting of ‚àº130similar-toabsent130{\sim}130,000000000 images. We consider a case with 444 parties, each storing a quadrant of each image. Each party trains ResNet50 locally and the server trains a single fully connected layer. We use a cross-entropy loss function with L2 regularization. The parties train using a batch size of 256256256. Each party trains using SGD with local momentum with œÅ=0.9ùúå0.9\rho=0.9. The initial learning rate for each party was selected from {0.3,0.08,0.03,0.008,0.003}0.30.080.030.0080.003\{0.3,0.08,0.03,0.008,0.003\} and the regularization coefficient was selected from {0,10‚àí3,10‚àí4,10‚àí5}0superscript103superscript104superscript105\{0,10^{-3},10^{-4},10^{-5}\}. The learning rate decays by a factor of 101010 every ‚àº75similar-toabsent75{\sim}75,000000000 local iterations.

ModelNet40: The ModelNet40 dataset are images of CAD models with 404040 classes of objects, each with 121212 different camera views. In our experiments, we consider a setup with 121212 parties, each with a single view of each CAD model. Each party trains ResNet50 locally and the server trains a single fully connected layer. We use a cross-entropy loss function for training. The parties train using a batch size of 646464. Each party trains using SGD with local momentum with œÅ=0.9ùúå0.9\rho=0.9. The learning rate for each party was selected from {1√ó10‚àí3,5√ó10‚àí4,1√ó10‚àí4,5√ó10‚àí5}1superscript1035superscript1041superscript1045superscript105\{1\times 10^{-3},5\times 10^{-4},1\times 10^{-4},5\times 10^{-5}\}.

Baselines: We compare Flex-VFL with synchronous and asynchronous VFL methods. We limit our comparisons to those that support arbitrary party feature extractors and arbitrary server fusion networks, as well as multiple local iterations¬†[8, 7, 14].

  • ‚Ä¢

    Sync-VFL Synchronous VFL is a special case of Flex-VFL where all parties run the same number of local iterations, regardless of party operating speeds. When parties all use standard SGD and the server model has no trainable parameters, Sync-VFL is equivalent to the VFL algorithm proposed by Liu et al¬†[7]. For our experiments, we consider two cases of Sync-VFL: Sync-Min-VFL and Sync-Max-VFL.

    • ‚Äì

      Sync-Min-VFL: Flex-VFL and Sync-VFL use the same choice of local training timeout, meaning each party in Sync-VFL runs œÑr=mink‚Å°œÑkrsuperscriptùúèùëüsubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau^{r}=\min_{k}\tau_{k}^{r} descent steps before synchronizing.

    • ‚Äì

      Sync-Max-VFL: Sync-VFL waits for all parties to run œÑr=maxk‚Å°œÑkrsuperscriptùúèùëüsubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau^{r}=\max_{k}\tau_{k}^{r} descent steps before synchronizing. This means that Sync-Max-VFL ensures that all parties run the same number of iterations as the fastest party in Flex-VFL, which extends the duration of a global round to accommodate the slowest party.

  • ‚Ä¢

    VAFL: In VAFL¬†[14], each party calculates its embeddings for a randomly selected mini-batch. The party then immediately exchanges information with the server to update both the server model and party‚Äôs model parameters. Parties may take different lengths of time to execute their individual training steps, and so the model updates are asynchronous.

  • ‚Ä¢

    P-BCD: We also include a baseline for Flex-VFL where we set œÑkr=1superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü1\tau_{k}^{r}=1 for all kùëòk and rùëür. This is equivalent to parallel block coordinate descent (P-BCD)¬†[56].

Time units: In each of our experiments, we measure time-to-target in terms of simulated time units. We define the communication time with the server, the computation time for each party, and the local training timeout to be used by Flex-VFL and Sync-VFL in terms of these time units. The time units taken to complete a local iteration and the timeout chosen inform how many local iterations each party will perform in Flex-VFL and Sync-VFL. For example, suppose two parties take 555 and 101010 time units to complete a local iteration, respectively, and the timeout is set to 202020. In Sync-VFL, both parties will complete two local iterations. In Flex-VFL, the first party will complete four local iterations while the second party completes two.

VII-B Heterogeneous Optimizers

We first study the effect of training with heterogeneous optimizers. We run Flex-VFL and train on the MOSEI dataset with parties either using standard SGD or SGD with local momentum. We consider a case where all parties and the server have the same operating rate. We let the computation time for each party be 111 time unit and set the timeout for each global round to be 202020 time units. Thus, each party runs 202020 local iterations in each global round. We let the communication latency be 101010 time units. We measure the average time taken to achieve a target mean-square error (MAE) over 555 runs. The results are given in Table¬†II. The best optimizer combination over the five runs is using standard SGD at the video and audio parties that train LSTMs, while the text party uses SGD with local momentum to train the BERT model. Thus we can see a benefit from choosing different optimizers at each party depending on the local model architecture. We use this combination of optimizers for the rest of the experiments with the MOSEI dataset.

VII-C Fixed Operating Speeds

We next study the setting where party operating speeds are heterogeneous but remain fixed throughout training. For each dataset we define the speed of a party by how many time units it takes for it to complete a local iteration, as well as a local training timeout to be used by Flex-VFL and Sync-VFL.

For MOSEI, we set the timeout to 202020 time units, and set the operating rates such that the parties storing video, audio, and text take 555, 101010, and 151515 local iterations before the timeout, respectively, while the server completes 202020 local iterations before the timeout. For ImageNet100, we set the timeout to 101010 time units, and set the operating rates such that the four parties take 222, 444, 666, and 888 local iterations before the timeout, respectively, while the server completes 101010 local iterations. For ModelNet40, we set the timeout to 202020 time units, set the operating rates such that server take 202020 local iterations before the timeout, and let groups of 333 parties each take 555, 101010, 151515, and 202020 local iterations, respectively. These operating rates are chosen such that there are an equal number of stragglers, medium speed parties, and fast parties in the system.

We simulate three communication network settings, representing cases of different ratios of computation time versus communication time. We denote the round-trip message latency with the server as tcommsubscriptùë°commt_{\mathrm{comm}} and we let the time for the fastest party to complete a local iteration be 111 time unit. In the first setting, we assume communication latency with the server is very low, equal to computation time of a single local iteration, and let tcomm=1subscriptùë°comm1t_{\mathrm{comm}}=1 unit. In the second setting, we consider a case where communication time starts to outweigh computation time of a single local iteration, and set tcomm=10subscriptùë°comm10t_{\mathrm{comm}}=10 units. In this case, communication with the server takes 101010 local iterations at the fastest party. For the final setting, we consider the case where there is very high communication latency, setting tcomm=50subscriptùë°comm50t_{\mathrm{comm}}=50 units. Such high communication latency can occur when parties are globally distributed.

In Table¬†III we show the time units it takes to reach a target test accuracy. For the MOSEI dataset, we let the target be 0.650.650.65 Mean Absolute Error (MAE), a common measure of performance for the dataset. We can see that for the MOSEI dataset, P-BCD and VAFL perform best when communication latency is low. However, as communication latency increases, Flex-VFL is able to reach the target MAE twice as fast as Sync-Min-VFL and P-BCD, and four times as fast as VAFL. For the ImageNet100 dataset, the target is set to 60%percent6060\% top-555 accuracy. In this case, P-BCD performs well when communication latency is low. As the communication latency increases however, Flex-VFL overtakes P-BCD, benefiting from local iterations saving on overall communication. Finally, for the ModelNet40 dataset, the target is set to 70%percent7070\%. Here, Flex-VFL always performs better than the other algorithms, regardless of communication latency. In our experiments with ModelNet40, there are a larger number of parties than in the other datasets. This causes the heterogeneity of party operating speeds to have a greater effect on time-to-target accuracy. With the chosen distribution of party operating speeds, Flex-VFL reaches a target accuracy up to four times as fast than other VFL algorithms. In the next subsection, we consider how different operating speed distributions can affect performance of each VFL algorithm.

VII-D Uniform Versus Average Operating Rates

For our next experiment, we again consider fixed operating speeds, and now focus on the effect of operating rate distribution. Specifically, we compare an evenly distributed case of party operating speeds to a typical case, and show how Flex-VFL, Sync-VFL, VAFL, and P-BCD perform. For these experiments, we use the ModelNet40 dataset, and consider two distributions of party operating speeds. For Flex-VFL and Sync-VFL, we use a local training timeout of 202020 time units. The first distribution is the same as the previous experiment: the timeout is set to 202020 time units, and the operating rates are set such that the server takes 202020 local iterations per round, and groups of 333 parties each take 555, 101010, 151515, and 202020 local iterations, respectively. For determining a realistic typical case of party operating speeds, we use Google‚Äôs Cluster Data¬†[57], a dataset of workload traces running on Google compute cells. We choose 131313 random traces from the dataset, and take the average CPU usage for each to determine the operating speed of parties for these experiments. For a party kùëòk, we let the time to complete a local iteration be (1‚àíck)‚àí1superscript1subscriptùëêùëò1(1-c_{k})^{-1} for all rùëür rounds, where cksubscriptùëêùëòc_{k} is the kùëòk-th machine‚Äôs average CPU utilization. Since the timeout is 202020 time units, œÑkr=20‚ãÖ(1‚àíck)superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü‚ãÖ201subscriptùëêùëò\tau_{k}^{r}=20\cdot(1-c_{k}) for all rùëür rounds.

In Figure¬†2 we present the results of training with the different operating rate distributions. We plot the top-555 test accuracy against time units. In Figures¬†2(a) and 2(b), we see the results when party operating speeds are evenly distributed. In this case, we can see that when communication time is low, Flex-VFL and VAFL perform well, as they are robust to the stragglers in the system. P-BCD also performs well here. We believe this is because P-BCD does not incur error introduced by local iterations. When communication latency is high though, we can see that Flex-VFL continues to perform well while VAFL and P-BCD start to perform worse. In Figures¬†2(c) and 2(d), we see the results for operating speeds using the Google Cluster data. In this case, we can see that Flex-VFL performs the same or better than Sync-Min-VFL and P-BCD when communication latency is low. When communication latency is high, Flex-VFL performs the same or better than Sync-Max-VFL. Flex-VFL in these cases is always the best choice of algorithm regardless of party operating rate distributions or communication time.

VII-E Effect of Local Training Timeout

In this section, we explore the effect of different timeouts with fixed operating rates on the time-to-target accuracy of Flex-VFL. For these experiments, we use the ModelNet40 dataset and use the even distribution of operating rates from previous experiments. We let the communication time be 101010 time units. We also include results from Sync-Max-VFL as a baseline. Recall that Sync-Max-VFL ensures all parties to run the same number of local iterations as the fastest party does in Flex-VFL. For example, if the fastest party in Flex-VFL runs 202020 local iterations, then all parties in Sync-Max-VFL run 202020 local iterations.

Table¬†IV shows the time taken for Sync-VFL and Flex-VFL to achieve 70%percent7070\% top-555 accuracy on the ModelNet40 dataset for different timeouts. We see that for Flex-VFL, increasing the timeout improves the time-to-target, up until a timeout of 404040 time units. We see this same trend with Sync-VFL when changing the number of local iterations. This is in line with previous works that explore the effect of local iterations on convergence rate¬†[7, 58, 3]. Increasing the number of local iterations improves time-to-target up to a certain point, where the error incurred by local iterations outweighs the benefits to convergence rate. We can also see in Table¬†IV that Flex-VFL outperforms Sync-VFL regardless of the timeout.

VII-F Variable Operating Speeds

We next investigate the setting where party operating speeds change during training. To model realistic changes in these rates, we again use Google‚Äôs Cluster Data¬†[57]. In Figure¬†3, we plot the CPU utilization of 444 randomly chosen machine traces over a short time interval. For a party kùëòk, we let the time to complete a local iteration be (1‚àíckr)‚àí1superscript1superscriptsubscriptùëêùëòùëü1(1-c_{k}^{r})^{-1} where ckrsuperscriptsubscriptùëêùëòùëüc_{k}^{r} is the kùëòk-th machine‚Äôs CPU utilization at global round rùëür. We set œÑkr=to‚ãÖ(1‚àíckr)superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü‚ãÖsubscriptùë°ùëú1superscriptsubscriptùëêùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r}=t_{o}\cdot(1-c_{k}^{r}) for round rùëür, where tosubscriptùë°ùëút_{o} is the local training timeout.

We compare Flex-VFL and Adaptive Flex-VFL, and train on the ModelNet40 and MOSEI datasets. For ModelNet40, we use a timeout of 101010 time units and set Ak=0.0001subscriptùê¥ùëò0.0001A_{k}=0.0001, and for MOSEI, we use a timeout of 202020 time units and set Ak=0.000‚Äâ05subscriptùê¥ùëò0.00005A_{k}=$0.000\,05$ for the text party and Ak=0.001subscriptùê¥ùëò0.001A_{k}=0.001 for the other parties and server. In both cases, we let the communication time be 111 time unit. For static Flex-VFL, the server chooses Œ∑k=Œ∑krsubscriptùúÇùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}=\eta_{k}^{r} such that (14) is not violated at any point during training. This is determined using the largest value œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} over all rounds rùëür, which is 101010 for ModelNet40 and 202020 for MOSEI, corresponding to the case when the CPU utilization is ckr=0superscriptsubscriptùëêùëòùëü0c_{k}^{r}=0. Adaptive Flex-VFL, on the other hand, chooses Œ∑krsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëü\eta_{k}^{r} in each global round based on the previous rounds values of œÑkrsuperscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü\tau_{k}^{r} and max0‚â§t‚â§œÑkr‚àí1‚Å°wkr,tsubscript0ùë°superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëòùëüùë°\max_{0\leq t\leq\tau_{k}^{r}-1}w_{k}^{r,t}, as described in Algorithm¬†2.

In Figures¬†4(a) and 4(b), we show the top-555 test accuracy of training on the ModelNet40 and MOSEI datasets, respectively. We can see that Adaptive Flex-VFL reaches a much higher test accuracy and lower MAE in a shorter period of training than Flex-VFL. In ModelNet40, Adaptive Flex-VFL reaches a top-555 accuracy of 70%percent7070\% about 130130130 time units faster than Flex-VFL. In MOSEI, Adaptive Flex-VFL achieves an MAE of 0.650.650.65 about 707070 time units faster than Flex-VFL. Allowing the learning rates to increase when CPU utilization is lower can greatly improve the convergence rate of Flex-VFL.

VIII Conclusion

We proposed Flex-VFL, a vertical federated learning algorithm that learns on distributed, vertically-partitioned data in a system with heterogeneous parties. We analyzed Flex-VFL and showed the benefit of optimizers that utilize momentum or proximal steps in VFL settings. We also showed that convergence requires that each party‚Äôs learning rate is tailored to its operating speed and local optimizer. Based on this observation, we proposed Adaptive Flex-VFL, which optimizes party learning rates at each global round based on party operating speeds and optimizer parameters. In our experiments, we demonstrated that Flex-VFL can outperform both synchronous and asynchronous VFL algorithms, reaching a target accuracy up to 4√ó4\times faster than other VFL algorithms. Our experiments also indicate that Flex-VFL is often the best overall choice of VFL algorithms when it‚Äôs necessary to be flexible with high communication latency and different party operating rate distribution. We also provided experimental results comparing Adaptive Flex-VFL and Flex-VFL using real-world party operating speeds. We found that Adaptive Flex-VFL can improve time-to-target accuracy by 30%percent3030\% over Flex-VFL. In future work, we will explore the impact of partial participation of VFL parties on algorithm performance.

-A Additional Notation

We define

In order to get our weighted averaged on the left-hand side, we divide through by ‚àër=0R‚àí1‚àëk=0KŒ∑kr‚Äã‚àët=0œÑkr‚àí1wkr,tsuperscriptsubscriptùëü0ùëÖ1superscriptsubscriptùëò0ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëòùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùë°0superscriptsubscriptùúèùëòùëü1superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëòùëüùë°\sum_{r=0}^{R-1}\sum_{k=0}^{K}\eta_{k}^{r}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau_{k}^{r}-1}w_{k}^{r,t}, which completes the proof of Theorem¬†1.
